Award.AwardTitle: Research Experience for Undergraduates: Green Chemistry in Colorful Colorado
Award.AbstractNarration: This award from the Division of Chemistry (CHE) at the National Science Foundation supports the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at University of Colorado- Colorado Springs (UCCS). The REU Program will bring seven students to campus for ten weeks each summer to conduct Green Chemistry research. One important goal of this REU Site is to train future scientists from institutions with no research opportunities, including community colleges and four-year colleges having limited research opportunities. In this region, several of these campuses have a large percentage of underrepresented students. The theme of this project, Green Chemistry, is a field that has been developing exponentially in academic and industrial venues. This project especially features elements of atom economy, small-scale reactions and analyses, and reactions in aqueous media. Some of the scientific goals of this project include: developing novel ligands that can catalytically remediate heavy metals from soils and wastewater, detecting the presence of household chemicals, hormones, and endocrine-disrupting compounds in the environment, and developing a photocatalyst for splitting water into H2 and O2. One of the collaborative inorganic/organic/biochemistry projects uses the rapidly expanding synthetic field of azide-alkyne "click chemistry". Participating faculty members have a strong commitment to undergraduate research and aim to prepare students for the transition to graduate school and research careers. Students in this program will benefit from having experienced UCCS student and faculty researchers working alongside them in a brand-new, handicap-accessible facility especially designed for undergraduate student researchers. One goal is to create a life-long support community for REU students composed of the other REU students and faculty mentors, to help these students achieve their educational and career goals. Results of the experiments are to be made available to the scientific community-at-large on the UCCS REU web site and through publications and presentations at American Chemical Society meetings and Green Chemistry conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During each of the summers of 2013, 2014, and 2015 eight sophomore- and junior-level undergraduate students were sponsored to travel to and reside on the campus of the University of Colorado, Colorado Springs (UCCS) to participate in an intensive 10-week program focused on building scientific research skills in the area of Green Chemistry.  Faculty, staff, and other students from the UCCS Department of Chemistry & Biochemistry (the Department) worked closely with program participants, who generally matured from a state of dependence to one of independence with respect to planning and executing research activities.  Each program culminated in a poster session that was open to the public and highlighted the research results of each participant.  When appropriate, research was submitted for publication within peer- reviewed scientific journals.

For example, one participant (name not provided) chose to seek a summertime research-intensive experience because his home institution (Pikes Peak Community College) did not offer research experiences to supplement a classroom-based curriculum. This participant conducted research under both Allen Schoffstall and Sonja Braun-Sand, two faculty in the Department who direct active year-round research programs and are eager to leverage the expertise of their research teams to train students new to research.  His summertime research experience inspired this participant to transfer from his community college to a major research institution where he is currently pursuing a STEM-field major and actively conducting research as an undergraduate.  Further, this student is listed as a co-author on a journal article (Journal of Molecular Modeling) highlighting his work under the guidance of Dr. Braun-Sand.  Over the course of the three-year program, a total of 24 students worked on a total of 10 research projects supervised by eight faculty members. 

Particularly important in this program was the direct supervision of the participants by their faculty mentors, oftentimes through weekly 1-on-1 meetings and extensive time spent in the laboratory carrying out experiments. This scrutiny engendered faster and more thorough development of research prowess among the participants. This model of continuous and open lines of mentor/mentee communication enabled participants to quickly learn how to address research questions and to cope with experimental problems. Efforts by the students helped build their confidence in thinking critically about their research projects and motivated them to actively address future project challenges. Overall, promotion of extensive faculty mentor-participant interaction was found to enhance the development of program participants as scientists and improve the quality and quantity of research conducted during each 10-week program.

In addition to contributions made through the intellectual merit of participants’ research projects, the program strived for further impact: to train a diverse pool of students in research best-practices and promote their general professional development as scientists.  To enhance the diversity of the scientific workforce, national recruitment efforts targeted populations currently unrepresented in STEM-field professions.  Over the course of the three-year program, a total of 24 students participated (selected from a total applicant pool of 701), representing geographic diversity (ranging from Connecticut, to Pennsylvania, to Florida, to California), ethnic diversity (25% self-identified as members of ethnic populations currently underrepresented in STEM-fields), and 54% participation by females.   Additionally, research opportunities were provided to students lacking such opportunities at their home institutions—75% of participants came from an institution whose chemistry department did not have active National Science Foundation funding.  Professional development was promoted through participants taking part in workshops focused on: recognizing and promoting the role of science in society, improving scientific presentation skills, developing effective scientific posters, and navigating common ethical dilemmas in science.  Additionally, an outreach activity where participants presented the motivation for their summertime research projects (as well as a brief hands-on demonstration) to area middle school classrooms was conducted.  Program effectiveness was assessed relative to targeted outcomes through both internal (surveys and journaling activity) and external (hiring an external evaluator) measures.  Overall, a strong sense of community was developed among each summertime cohort, participants’ interest in pursuing an advanced education in the sciences was enhanced, and a scientific skillset (both in conducting experiments and in presenting results) was built.
